questions.question: Which of the following is included in gross income?

options.B: Alimony received under a 2019 divorce decree
options.C: Life insurance proceeds received by a beneficiary

questions.explanation: Under pre-2019 divorce agreements, alimony is taxable to the recipient and deductible by the payer. For divorces executed after 2018, alimony is neither taxable nor deductible. Child support, life insurance death benefits, and gifts are excluded from gross income.
questions.tip: Post-2018 divorces: alimony not taxable/deductible. Pre-2019: old rules apply unless modified.

questions.question: For 2024, the standard deduction for a married couple filing jointly is approximately:
questions.explanation: For 2024, the standard deduction is approximately $29,200 for married filing jointly, $14,600 for single and married filing separately, and $21,900 for head of household. Additional amounts are available for taxpayers who are blind or age 65+.
questions.tip: MFJ = approximately double the single amount. Know current year values for the exam.

questions.question: A scholarship used for which of the following is excluded from gross income?

options.B: Tuition and required course materials

questions.explanation: Qualified scholarships are excluded from income when used for tuition and fees required for enrollment, and course-related expenses such as books, supplies, and equipment. Room, board, travel, and personal expenses are taxable if paid by scholarship funds.
questions.tip: Excluded: tuition, fees, books, supplies. Taxable: room, board, travel, living expenses.

questions.question: An eligible educator can deduct up to how much for unreimbursed classroom expenses in 2024?
questions.explanation: Eligible educators (K-12 teachers with at least 900 hours) can deduct up to $300 of unreimbursed expenses for classroom supplies, books, and professional development. This is an above-the-line deduction, available even if the taxpayer doesn't itemize.
questions.tip: Educator expense = $300 above-the-line. Must be K-12 teacher working 900+ hours.

questions.question: The Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) is a:

options.B: Refundable credit for low to moderate income workers
options.C: Credit only for taxpayers with children

questions.explanation: The EITC is a refundable credit for low to moderate income workers. It's available with or without qualifying children (though the amount is much higher with children). Investment income must be below a threshold. Being refundable means the credit can result in a refund even with no tax liability.
questions.tip: EITC: refundable, needs earned income, investment income limit. Can receive even with zero tax liability.

questions.question: A single individual under age 65 must file a return if gross income equals or exceeds:

options.B: The standard deduction amount

questions.explanation: Generally, individuals must file if gross income equals or exceeds the standard deduction amount for their filing status. For a single person under 65 in 2024, this is approximately $14,600. Special rules require filing regardless of income in certain situations (e.g., self-employment income of $400+).
questions.tip: Filing threshold = standard deduction. But must file with SE income ≥ $400 regardless of total income.

questions.question: Which of the following fringe benefits is NOT excludable from an employee's gross income?

options.A: Health insurance premiums paid by employer
options.B: Qualified transportation benefits up to monthly limit
options.D: Employer-provided group term life insurance up to $50,000 coverage

questions.explanation: Personal use of an employer-provided vehicle is taxable compensation. Health insurance, qualified transportation (up to monthly limits), and group term life insurance up to $50,000 are excludable. The value of personal use must be included in the employee's W-2 income.
questions.tip: Personal use of company car = taxable. Business use = excludable. Must track and allocate.

questions.question: The maximum deduction for state and local taxes (SALT) for a married couple filing jointly is:
questions.explanation: The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act limits the itemized deduction for state and local taxes to $10,000 ($5,000 for married filing separately). This includes property taxes, state income taxes (or sales taxes if elected), and local taxes. The limitation is scheduled to expire after 2025.
questions.tip: SALT cap = $10,000 ($5,000 MFS). Includes property + income/sales taxes combined.

questions.question: Cash contributions to public charities are generally deductible up to what percentage of AGI?
questions.explanation: Cash contributions to public charities (50% limit organizations) are deductible up to 60% of AGI. Capital gain property is limited to 30% of AGI. Contributions to private foundations have lower limits. Excess contributions carry forward for 5 years.
questions.tip: Cash to public = 60%. Capital gain property = 30%. Private foundations = lower limits. 5-year carryforward.

questions.question: For 2024, the Child Tax Credit for each qualifying child under age 17 is:
questions.explanation: The Child Tax Credit is $2,000 per qualifying child under age 17. Up to $1,700 is refundable as the Additional Child Tax Credit. The credit phases out at $400,000 AGI for married filing jointly ($200,000 for others). A $500 credit is available for other dependents.
questions.tip: $2,000 per child < 17. Up to $1,700 refundable. Phaseout at $400K MFJ, $200K others.

questions.question: The maximum percentage of Social Security benefits that can be included in gross income is:
questions.explanation: Up to 85% of Social Security benefits may be taxable depending on provisional income (AGI + tax-exempt interest + 50% of benefits). If provisional income exceeds upper thresholds ($34,000 single, $44,000 MFJ), up to 85% is taxable. Between thresholds, up to 50% is taxable.
questions.tip: Max 85% taxable. Two thresholds: first triggers 50%, second triggers 85%. Never 100% taxable.

questions.question: To contribute to a Health Savings Account (HSA), a taxpayer must:

options.A: Be enrolled in any health insurance plan
options.B: Be covered under a high-deductible health plan (HDHP)

questions.explanation: HSA contributions require coverage under an HDHP and no other disqualifying coverage. Contributions are deductible above-the-line, grow tax-free, and are tax-free if used for qualified medical expenses. Those 55+ can make additional catch-up contributions. Medicare enrollment disqualifies new contributions.
questions.tip: HSA: HDHP required, no other coverage, not on Medicare. Triple tax benefit: deduction, tax-free growth, tax-free distributions.

questions.question: The American Opportunity Tax Credit maximum per student is:
questions.explanation: The AOTC provides a maximum credit of $2,500 per eligible student (100% of first $2,000 + 25% of next $2,000). 40% of the credit (up to $1,000) is refundable. It's available for the first 4 years of post-secondary education. AGI phaseouts apply.
questions.tip: AOTC: $2,500 max, 40% refundable ($1,000), first 4 years only. Lifetime Learning = $2,000, nonrefundable, no limit on years.

questions.question: Medical expenses are deductible to the extent they exceed what percentage of AGI?
questions.explanation: Medical expenses are deductible as an itemized deduction to the extent they exceed 7.5% of AGI. Qualifying expenses include doctor visits, prescriptions, hospital stays, and health insurance premiums. Cosmetic surgery and general health items typically don't qualify.
questions.tip: 7.5% of AGI floor. Include unreimbursed expenses for taxpayer, spouse, and dependents.

questions.question: A taxpayer covered by an employer retirement plan can fully deduct a traditional IRA contribution if:

options.A: AGI is below the phaseout threshold for their filing status
options.B: They are under age 50
options.D: They don't have a Roth IRA

questions.explanation: For taxpayers covered by an employer plan, the traditional IRA deduction phases out based on AGI and filing status. If AGI is below the phaseout range, the full deduction is allowed. Above the range, no deduction is allowed. A nondeductible contribution can still be made.
questions.tip: Active participant phaseouts vary by filing status. Single: ~$77K-$87K. MFJ: ~$123K-$143K (2024).

questions.question: Cancellation of debt income is generally excludable when the taxpayer is:

options.B: Insolvent to the extent of insolvency

questions.explanation: Cancellation of debt income can be excluded if the taxpayer is insolvent (liabilities exceed FMV of assets) to the extent of insolvency. Other exclusions apply for bankruptcy, qualified farm indebtedness, qualified real property business debt, and qualified principal residence indebtedness (through 2025).
questions.tip: Exclusion limited to amount of insolvency. Example: $50K insolvent, $80K COD = $50K excluded, $30K taxable.

questions.question: For mortgages originated after December 15, 2017, mortgage interest is deductible on acquisition debt up to:
questions.explanation: For mortgages originated after December 15, 2017, interest is deductible on acquisition debt up to $750,000 ($375,000 MFS). Pre-December 16, 2017 mortgages are grandfathered at the $1 million limit. Home equity loan interest is only deductible if used for home improvements (not other purposes).
questions.tip: Post-TCJA: $750K limit on acquisition debt. HELOC only deductible if used to buy, build, or improve the home.

questions.question: A self-employed individual can deduct health insurance premiums:

options.A: As an itemized deduction subject to AGI floor
options.B: As an above-the-line deduction up to net self-employment income

questions.explanation: Self-employed individuals can deduct 100% of health insurance premiums for themselves, spouse, and dependents as an above-the-line deduction. The deduction is limited to the net profit from the business. It's not available for months when the taxpayer is eligible for employer-subsidized coverage.
questions.tip: Above-the-line, limited to SE net profit. Not available if eligible for employer plan (even if spouse's).

questions.question: The Retirement Savings Contributions Credit (Saver's Credit) is available to:

options.A: All taxpayers who contribute to a retirement account
options.B: Low to moderate income taxpayers meeting AGI limits

questions.explanation: The Saver's Credit is a nonrefundable credit for eligible retirement contributions by low to moderate income taxpayers. The credit rate (50%, 20%, or 10%) depends on AGI and filing status. The maximum contribution eligible for credit is $2,000 per person.
questions.tip: Saver's Credit: up to 50% of first $2,000 contributed. Income limits are low. Nonrefundable.

questions.question: When an employer makes an interest-free loan to an employee, the tax consequences include:

options.A: No tax consequences until the loan is repaid
options.B: Imputed interest income to employer and compensation to employee
options.D: Tax only if the loan exceeds $100,000

questions.explanation: Below-market loans between employers and employees result in: (1) imputed compensation income to the employee equal to the foregone interest, and (2) imputed interest income to the employer (offset by compensation deduction if reasonable). The AFR determines the imputed interest rate.
questions.tip: Employer-employee loans: compensation to employee, interest income to employer. Gift loans = different treatment.

questions.question: Gambling losses are deductible:

options.A: In full regardless of gambling winnings
options.B: As an above-the-line deduction
options.C: As an itemized deduction limited to gambling winnings

questions.explanation: Gambling losses are deductible as an itemized deduction, but only to the extent of gambling winnings reported as income. They cannot create or increase a net loss. Professional gamblers may have different treatment under business deduction rules.
questions.tip: Losses limited to winnings. All winnings taxable, losses only deductible if itemizing.

questions.question: The kiddie tax applies to unearned income of a child who is:

options.B: Under age 19 (or under 24 if a full-time student) with unearned income exceeding the threshold
options.D: Only children with no earned income

questions.explanation: The kiddie tax applies to children under 19 (or under 24 if full-time students not self-supporting) whose unearned income exceeds the threshold (approximately $2,500 in 2024). The excess is taxed at the parents' marginal rate. The first portion is tax-free, the second is taxed at the child's rate.
questions.tip: Under 19, or under 24 if full-time student. Unearned income over threshold taxed at parents' rate.

questions.question: The Section 199A qualified business income deduction is:

options.B: An itemized deduction
options.C: A deduction in computing taxable income, not AGI

questions.explanation: The QBI deduction is taken in computing taxable income, not AGI. It's available to non-corporate taxpayers with qualified business income from pass-through entities or sole proprietorships. The deduction is up to 20% of QBI, subject to W-2 wage and capital limitations above income thresholds.
questions.tip: QBI deduction reduces taxable income, not AGI. Available whether itemizing or using standard deduction.

questions.question: Which of the following is a specified service trade or business (SSTB) that faces QBI deduction limitations?

options.B: Engineering

questions.explanation: SSTBs include health, law, accounting, actuarial science, performing arts, consulting, athletics, financial services, and any business where the principal asset is reputation or skill. Engineering and architecture are specifically excluded. SSTB income is limited or excluded from QBI deduction above income thresholds.
questions.tip: SSTBs: health, law, accounting, consulting, financial services. NOT: engineering, architecture, real estate.

questions.question: For tax years beginning after 2020, net operating losses (NOLs) can offset:

options.A: 100% of taxable income with no carryback
options.B: 80% of taxable income with 2-year carryback
options.C: 80% of taxable income with no carryback and indefinite carryforward

questions.explanation: Post-2020 NOLs are limited to 80% of taxable income, cannot be carried back (except for farming losses), and carry forward indefinitely. Pre-2018 NOLs had a 2-year carryback, 20-year carryforward, and could offset 100% of income. The CARES Act temporarily modified these rules for 2018-2020.
questions.tip: Post-2020: 80% limit, no carryback, indefinite carryforward. Pre-2018 NOLs retain old rules.

questions.question: Which of the following is an exception to the 10% early withdrawal penalty from a traditional IRA?

options.B: Withdrawal for first home purchase (up to $10,000 lifetime)
options.D: Withdrawal to pay credit card debt

questions.explanation: Exceptions to the 10% penalty include first-time home purchase (up to $10,000 lifetime), qualified higher education expenses, birth/adoption expenses (up to $5,000), health insurance if unemployed, unreimbursed medical expenses exceeding 7.5% of AGI, disability, and SEPP payments.
questions.tip: Key exceptions: first home ($10K), education, medical >7.5% AGI, disability, SEPP, birth/adoption.

questions.question: The foreign tax credit is limited to:

options.B: U.S. tax liability × (foreign source income / worldwide income)
options.D: The lesser of $10,000 or foreign taxes paid

questions.explanation: The foreign tax credit limitation prevents U.S. taxpayers from using foreign taxes to offset U.S. tax on U.S. source income. The limit is: (Pre-credit U.S. tax) × (Foreign source taxable income / Worldwide taxable income). Excess credits carry back 1 year and forward 10 years.
questions.tip: FTC limit = US tax × (foreign income / worldwide income). Excess carries back 1, forward 10 years.

questions.question: Under the constructive receipt doctrine, income is taxable when:

options.B: It is credited, set apart, or made available without substantial restrictions
options.C: The taxpayer deposits it in a bank account

questions.explanation: Constructive receipt applies when income is credited to the taxpayer's account, set apart for them, or made available so they can draw upon it, even if not physically received. Substantial limitations or restrictions delay constructive receipt. This prevents taxpayers from choosing when to recognize income.
questions.tip: Available without restriction = constructively received. Can't turn your back on income to defer it.

questions.question: Required minimum distributions (RMDs) from traditional IRAs must begin by April 1 following the year the account owner reaches age:
questions.explanation: Under SECURE 2.0, RMDs must begin by April 1 following the year the account owner reaches age 73 (for those born 1951-1959). Age 75 applies for those born 1960 or later. Failure to take RMDs results in a 25% penalty (reduced to 10% if corrected timely).
questions.tip: RMD age: 73 (born 1951-1959), 75 (born 1960+). First RMD by April 1, subsequent by Dec 31.

questions.question: The Child and Dependent Care Credit is based on employment-related expenses up to:

options.A: $3,000 for one qualifying individual, $6,000 for two or more
options.B: $5,000 for one qualifying individual, $10,000 for two or more
options.C: $8,000 for one qualifying individual, $16,000 for two or more

questions.explanation: The credit is based on employment-related expenses up to $3,000 for one qualifying individual or $6,000 for two or more. The credit percentage ranges from 20-35% based on AGI (20% for AGI over $43,000). The temporary increased limits from 2021 have expired.
questions.tip: $3,000 one, $6,000 two+. Credit = 20-35% depending on AGI. Both spouses must work (or be students/disabled).

questions.question: Excess business losses for noncorporate taxpayers are:

options.A: Fully deductible in the current year
options.B: Limited and carried forward as part of NOL

questions.explanation: Under Section 461(l), excess business losses (losses exceeding $305,000 single or $610,000 MFJ for 2024) are not allowed in the current year. The disallowed amount is carried forward and treated as part of the NOL. This limitation applies before the passive loss rules.
questions.tip: EBL applies before passive loss rules. Threshold indexed for inflation. Disallowed becomes NOL carryforward.

questions.question: For nonqualified stock options (NQSOs), ordinary income is recognized:

options.B: When the option is exercised, equal to the spread

questions.explanation: For NQSOs, ordinary income equal to the 'spread' (FMV at exercise minus exercise price) is recognized at exercise. This is subject to income tax withholding. Subsequent appreciation is capital gain. Employer receives a deduction when employee recognizes income.
questions.tip: NQSO: ordinary income at exercise. ISO: no income at exercise, AMT adjustment possible, special holding period.

questions.question: Investment interest expense is deductible to the extent of:

options.A: Total interest paid during the year
options.B: Net investment income

questions.explanation: Investment interest expense is an itemized deduction limited to net investment income (interest, dividends not qualifying for preferential rates, net short-term capital gains). Capital gains and qualified dividends can be included in investment income if the taxpayer elects, but then they're taxed at ordinary rates.
questions.tip: Limited to net investment income. Can elect to include capital gains/qualified dividends, but lose preferential rates.

questions.question: The Premium Tax Credit for health insurance purchased on the marketplace is:

options.A: Available only at tax filing time
options.B: A refundable credit that can be received in advance
options.C: Limited to taxpayers with no employer coverage offered

questions.explanation: The Premium Tax Credit is a refundable credit that helps eligible individuals and families pay for marketplace health insurance. It can be paid in advance directly to the insurer or claimed at filing. Eligibility is based on household income between 100-400% of the federal poverty level (with expanded eligibility through 2025).
questions.tip: Refundable, can be advanced. Based on income 100-400% FPL. Must reconcile on return—may owe or get refund.

questions.question: Qualified dividends are taxed at:

options.B: A flat 15% rate for all taxpayers

questions.explanation: Qualified dividends receive preferential rates of 0%, 15%, or 20% based on taxable income. The 0% rate applies up to the top of the 12% bracket, 15% for income above that through the start of the 37% bracket, and 20% for the highest bracket. The 3.8% NIIT may also apply.
questions.tip: Same rates as long-term capital gains: 0/15/20% based on income. Plus possible 3.8% NIIT.
